para.text: Basin Design
This section is used to describe the characteristics of the infiltration basin.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Basin Shape

The infiltration basin can be specified as square, rectangular, or circular with user-specified dimensions of length, length and width, or diameter respectively. Analytical results for rectangular and square basins are subject to greater numerical error because a lookup table is used in the calculation. With typical values of the aquifer parameters, this numerical error is not normally a problem.
For a custom basin shape, there is no analytical solution and a numerical solution must be employed instead.
Basin Depth
This is the depth of water in the basin.
Basin Area
This is the area of the basin. It is calculated from the dimensions of the basin.

para.text: Diameter of Basin

These X and Y coordinates define the shape of a custom basin. Custom basins can only be used with a numerical model. The centroid of the basin will be placed at the center of the numerical model.

para.text: Aquifer Properties

This section is used to define the properties of the soil and underlying aquifer that affect the rate at which water can infiltrate and how the aquifer will respond to the infiltrating ground water and the amount of time that will be simulated.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Vertical Hydraulic Conductivity

Hydraulic conductivity is a measure of the ease with which water will move through a completely saturated media. It is also referred to as field-saturated hydraulic conductivity, or soil permeability. It is a measure of the ease with which water will move through soil. The vertical hydraulic conductivity controls the rate water will infiltrate (as it is modeled in this application) and is also referred to as the infiltration rate. Hydraulic conductivity is often measured in the horizontal direction. The vertical hydraulic conductivity is typically lower than the horizontal hydraulic conductivity because of horizontally oriented grains of sediment (on a micro-scale) and horizontal layers with low hydraulic conductivity (on a macro-scale) that impede vertical flow to a greater extent than horizontal flow.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Horizontal Hydraulic Conductivity

Whereas the vertical hydraulic conductivity controls the speed with which infiltrating water will infiltrate past the basin bottom and reach the water table, horizontal hydraulic conductivity helps controls the speed with which water will move laterally away from locations where the water table is higher (such as the location where water is infiltrating). Horizontal hydraulic conductivity is typically higher than vertical hydraulic conductivity. If geotechnical boring data are available, use these data to estimate the vertical and/or horizontal hydraulic conductivity.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Specific Yield

The specific yield is a measure of how much water is released by draining a block of aquifer. It is expressed as a fraction. The specific yield is less than the porosity because not all the water contained in an aquifer will drain out of it; some will remain as coatings on grains or in small pores. This lower limit of soil water content may be taken as the wilting point or residual water left after overpressure extraction at 15 MPa.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Depth to Seasonal High Water Table
This is the distance from the bottom of the infiltration basin to the water table.

anchor.style: font-family:Arial; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Initial Saturated Aquifer Thickness
The initial aquifer thickness is measured from the base of the aquifer to the seasonal high water table. The unsaturated zone above the water table should not be included in the aquifer thickness.
Duration of Infiltration

The duration of infiltration is calculated automatically from the basin depth and the vertical hydraulic conductivity. The user can specify a longer time than the automatically calculated value. However, doing so implies that either the basin area or vertical hydraulic conductivity is wrong.

para.text: Run Analytical Model

This page is used for setting controls that only apply to the Hantush (1967) analytical model and to run the analytical model. The analytical model does not take into account the vertical component of flow within the aquifer and can only be used for a square, rectangular or circular infiltration basin. The solution is less accurate when the rise in water table is large compared to the initial aquifer thickness and should only be considered valid if the rise in the water table is less than 50% of the aquifer thickness.

The duration of the infiltration is determined by dividing the basin depth by the vertical hydraulic conductivity (soil permeability). The recharge rate (also called the percolation rate or infiltration rate) does not vary during the duration of infiltration (as would be the actual case with declining head of standing water in the basin).
The infiltrating water is assumed to reach the water table instantaneously.
To perform the analytical simulation, click the
Get model results
button. The results will be displayed on the graph and tabulated in the profile table. The graph and table can be copied to the clipboard. The tables can be saved to comma-separated value files. For
basins, the solution must meet certain acceptability criteria to be plotted and saved. The criteria are most often not met for long distances and short times after the end of infiltration.
Simulation Length

The simulation length is the total amount of time that will be simulated measured from the beginning of infiltration to some time after infiltration has ceased and the groundwater mound is spreading outwards and dissipating.

This determines how far from the center of the basin results from the analytical solution will be reported.

para.text: Time Increment Between Results

The first analytical simulation result is calculated at the end of the recharge (infiltration) period when the rise in the water table beneath the infiltration basin is at a maximum. Additional analytical simulation results can be calculated to show the decay of the groundwater mound after infiltration ceases. The time increment determines the amount of time between these subsequent simulations.

para.text: Unsaturated Flow

Flow through the unsaturated media is different than flow through saturated media, and can be explicitly simulated using the numerical model. Simulating the unsaturated zone may result in a lower maximum height of the groundwater mound because the infiltrating water will reach the water table over a longer period of time, thus giving the groundwater mound more time to spread out. See Niswonger and others (2006) for details.
Simulating flow through the unsaturated zone can be a time-consuming process. Some models may require several hours to run to completion.

This is the fraction of the aquifer volume occupied by water when the aquifer is fully saturated.

para.text: Initial or Antecedent Water Content

This is the fraction of the unsaturated zone occupied by water prior to the beginning of infiltration from a new storm event. The saturated water content minus the initial water content represents the capacity of the soil for storing additional moisture.

para.text: Program Locations

Running the numerical model requires two external programs: MODFLOW (Harbaugh, 2005) and ModelMuse (Winston, 2009). This program creates a ModelMuse file. It then uses ModelMuse to create the input files for MODFLOW, runs MODFLOW and extracts the model results. MODFLOW and ModelMuse must be installed separately from GwMound.

para.text: Run Numerical Model
This page is used for running the numerical model and displaying its results. When the
Run numeric model
button is clicked, the numeric model will be created and started. It may take several minutes to run the model. When it is done, the results will be graphed and displayed in tables (See

). The graph and profile table show the highest rise in the water table in any of the model time steps. It does not represent the profile at any one point in time. The user should also examine the summary table especially the percent discrepancy. If the percent discrepancy is greater than 1%, there is a problem with the model and it may be necessary to modify the template for the model in order to overcome the problem. The graph and tables can be copied to the clipboard. The tables can be saved to comma-separated value files.

The numerical model is a MODFLOW-2005 model with 691 rows and columns and 6 layers. The water table is in the top layer which is unconfined. (Strictly speaking the top is convertible between confined and unconfined but the top of the layer is 200 m above the water table so it would take a very large rise in the water table before the layer would convert to confined.) Because the model has multiple layers, it
explicitly simulates

vertical flow - something the analytical model can not do. In the center of the model where the recharge is applied, the cells are 1 meter long and 1 meter wide. This size increases to 8 meter by 8 meter at the edge of the grid. The total length and width of the model are both 2001 meters. The numerical model is saved in a subfolder of a folder named "GwMounding_Numerical_Models" under your "My Documents" folder.
Simulation Length
The simulation length is the total amount of time that will be simulated, starting at the beginning of infiltration.
